stories.text: For years weâ€™ve been reading about how vulnerable so many computer systems, especially ones using Intel and AMD processors, are highly vulnerable to speculative execution attacks such as Spectre, Meltdown, Foreshadow and Fallout. Numerous demonstrations of the feasibility of these attacks have been published, seemingly showing their practicality (even in JavaScript). Microcode updates that partially mitigate them have meant significant performance slowdowns, also suggesting their practicality. Are there many cases where these vulnerabilities have led to actual breaches of real-world systems?
stories.title: Ask HN: Real-World Breaches from Speculative Execution Vulns?

stories.text:
Backstory: My family is in Arkansas and they just texted me to let me know there was a mass shooting with one dead and 24 wounded. Early local news reports say multiple people were shooting into the crowd at a car show.

Question: I was kinda stunned this wasn't on the front page of NY Times or Wapo or Fox? I don't expect it be the very top, but when does a mass shooting actually become national news? What is the criteria?
stories.title: Ask HN: Does anyone know what numbers make gun violence national news?
Opinion: The Senate accidentally agreed to move our clocks forward
